channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald National Headlines
channel.description: The top National headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: Gillard on the nose as state leaders face voters
item.description: THE Victorian Labor Leader, Daniel Andrews, has sought to firewall Julia Gillard from a looming Greens victory in next week's Melbourne state byelection, saying it would be wrong to attribute such a result to disenchantment with the federal government.

item.title: Opposition seeks answer on Labor's boat action
item.description: THE opposition is demanding to know why the recent spate of boats that sent distress calls when just off the Indonesian coast had not been returned to Indonesia.

item.title: Protesters step up campaign against nuclear waste dump
item.description: THE Northern Territory government has accused the Commonwealth of exploiting ''political expediency'' by pushing ahead with plans for a nuclear waste dump in the top end.

item.title: Quality courses the key to Asian market, educators told
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S higher education sector has been challenged to focus on quality if it is to regain its position as a major destination for Chinese students.

item.title: Force urges troops to re-enlist after mining civvy riches
item.description: THE Defence Force has to become better at allowing people to return to military service if they step out of uniform for a few years to accrue ''nest eggs'' in boom sectors like mining, the Defence chief has said.

item.title: No place for blind eye to behaviour, says general
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S top general has acknowledged the Defence Force has failed to properly care for victims of abuse, and is urging his members to not ''turn a blind eye'' to abuse in its ranks, following the release of a highly damaging report about 60 years of unreported bastardisation.

item.title: Dark side of the online shopping boom: credit card fraud soars
item.description: ONE IN 15 adults was the victim of credit card fraud over the past year with losses blowing out to a record $278 million as the online shopping boom leads to more Australians being swindled.

item.title: NSW, Victoria post biggest drop in house prices
item.description: HOUSE prices fell 2 per cent in the June quarter, and more falls are expected in the coming year, especially in the most populous states of NSW and Victoria, National Australia Bank says.

item.title: Canberra defends data retention plan
item.description: THE Gillard government has defended a plan to force telcos to store internet and phone data of all Australians for up to two years, saying it is needed to allow intelligence and police agencies to effectively target organised criminals and terrorists.

item.title: Labor axes trio in bid to rebuild
item.description: NSW LABOR has suspended three of its most controversial members in an attempt to distance the party from the scandals that engulfed the former state government as it tries to rebuild after last year's election loss.

item.title: Precious pink sparkler lights up museum
item.description: ''IT'S glamorous and pretentious, and billions of years old,'' says the co-director of jeweller Mondial Pink Diamond Atelier, Michael Neuman. ''Everything you want in a diamond.''

item.title: Syrian doctor's pleas for help fell on deaf ears - WikiLeaks
item.description: A DESPERATE plea for asylum by a doctor trying to escape violence and possible execution in Syria and the Australian embassy's bureaucratic response to him are among more than 2 million Syrian emails obtained by WikiLeaks.

item.title: Rampaging price rises to stop, says energy boss
item.description: THE new head of the state's highly profitable power distributors, Vince Graham, has told staff that prices must be held to rises in the overall inflation rate â€“ or less.

item.title: Another home shot at in Sydney's west
item.description: Gunshots have been fired at a home in Sydney's west.

item.title: Labor suspends NSW trio: report
item.description: The Labor Party in NSW has suspended three well-known members, including a union boss and two ex-MPs, according to a media report.

item.title: Police close in on Mackay remains: report
item.description: Homicide detectives are reportedly closing in on the remains of NSW anti-drugs campaigner Donald Mackay.

item.title: Muralidaran joins Renegades in T20
item.description: Cricket legend Muttiah Muralidaran will play in Australia's Twenty20 cricket competition for the Melbourne Renegades this season.

item.title: Lewis' interest proves Sharks credentials
item.description: The finals-bound Sharks say Cronulla would be the perfect destination for NSW backrower Luke Lewis to call his new home.

item.title: Murphy, Henderson back for AFL's Blues
item.description: Carlton AFL midfielder Marc Murphy and key defender Lachie Henderson have both been selected to return from injury against North Melbourne on Friday night.

item.title: Essendon lose Paddy Ryder with calf injury
item.description: Essendon's top-four quest has got harder with ruckman Paddy Ryder facing several weeks on the AFL sidelines with another Bombers' soft tissue injury

item.title: Demons lose Davey for AFL season
item.description: Aaron Davey's stop-start AFL season is over for Melbourne, with scans revealing a stress fracture in his foot.

item.title: Eagle Cox ready to soar up front v Swans
item.description: Eagles AFL ruckman Dean Cox is expected to play a significant role in the forwards against the Swans in the absence of suspended Quinten Lynch.

item.title: Eight Super Rugby sides in final shoot-out
item.description: The rugby gods and mother nature will help decide which eight finals-contending teams make the Super Rugby top six and where.

item.title: SBW no certainty for Kiwis World Cup
item.description: New Zealand rugby league chief executive Jim Doyle is unsure if Sonny Bill Williams will be part of the Kiwis' world cup squad next year.

item.title: NRL's All Stars game moves to Brisbane
item.description: The annual NRL All Stars clash will be played at Suncorp Stadium next year as the event continues to grow.

item.title: Seoul not to go ahead on whaling: Carr
item.description: Australia's Foreign Affairs Minister Bob Carr has been told that South Korea is not going ahead with scientifc whaling.

item.title: Dockers hand Walters a second chance
item.description: Fremantle goalsneak Michael Walters has learned the hard way about what's required to succeed in the AFL.

item.title: Our jobless low by world standards: PM
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard says the jobless rate remains low by world standards, despite edging up to 5.2 per cent in the latest labour force numbers.

item.title: Moffatt misses triathlon champ Snowsill
item.description: Australian triathlete Emma Moffatt says she was upset when Olympic champion Emma Snowsill was overlooked for the London Games.

item.title: Folau undecided about long-term future
item.description: AFL convert Israel Folau says he wants to serve out his contract with GWS until the end of 2014, but is unsure about what will happen then.

item.title: Raiders' NRL form on song for 3 in a row
item.description: Canberra recruit Sandor Earl says it's not time to talk about the possibility of NRL finals, but two wins from two has hopes renewed.

item.title: Payments fraud rises by $77.5m in 2011
item.description: Payments fraud rose by $77.5 million to $300.8 million in 2011, according to the Australian Payments Clearing Association (APCA).

item.title: Coles says retailing is more competitive
item.description: Supermarket operator Coles says overseas chains with "deep pockets" are making the retail environment more competitive.

item.title: Eels NRL coach Kearney clinging to hope
item.description: Parramatta NRL coach Stephen Kearney is under no illusions as to the size of the task his side face when they take on Canterbury on Friday.

item.title: Turner signs new NRL deal with Bulldogs
item.description: Former State of Origin winger Steve Turner says he is happy to have settled his future after signing a one-year contract extension with Canterbury.

item.title: Two Australian soldiers wounded by Afghan bomb
item.description: Two Australian soldiers were wounded in southern Afghanistan when a roadside bomb exploded against a Bushmaster vehicle, authorities say.

item.title: Two diggers wounded by Afghan bomb
item.description: Two Australian soldiers were wounded in southern Afghanistan following the detonation of a roadside bomb on Tuesday.

item.title: Sydney chef stabbed in altercation: court
item.description: An exchange of verbal taunts preceded the stabbing murder of a young Sydney chef after a night out with friends, court documents allege.

item.title: AFL bans costly for Tigers: Hardwick
item.description: Richmond coach Damien Hardwick says missing three players to suspension for Saturday's AFL clash with Gold Coast is something the club can ill afford.

item.title: Storm's super Cronk hits 200 NRL games
item.description: Melbourne halfback Cooper Cronk is preparing to play North Queensland in his 200th NRL game but, in typical fashion, is shunning the spotlight.

item.title: Crusaders aim to rain on Sharpe's parade
item.description: The Crusaders are on red alert for an emotionally-charged Western Force outfit eager to celebrate Nathan Sharpe's final Super Rugby game with a win.

item.title: Schoolboys to get Gardasil vaccine
item.description: In a world first, Australian schoolboys will be vaccinated against conditions such as genital warts, and some cancers, under a new immunisation program announced by the federal government.

item.title: Broncos expect late Warriors NRL inclusion
item.description: Brisbane are preparing for centre Konrad Hurrell to play in their NRL clash with the Warriors despite not being named due to a leg injury.

item.title: NBN signs $280m deal for satellite dishes
item.description: The builder of the NBN has signed a $280 million contract with ViaSat Inc to manufacture satellite dishes and other equipment for the network's rollout.

item.title: Blues uncertainty a boost for Brumbies
item.description: Brumbies coach Jake White says the Blues will start with a disadvantage given Pat Lam's ongoing battle to extend his contract.

item.title: Sex abuse claims badly handled: Abbott
item.description: Federal opposition leader and prominent Catholic Tony Abbott says allegations of abuse of children by members of the church have been appallingly handled.

item.title: Kangaroos can keep up AFL pace: Scott
item.description: North Melbourne coach Brad Scott is confident his AFL side has the endurance to see out games, despite some poor last quarters this season.

item.title: Myer axes 100 jobs amid retail gloom
item.description: Myer will axe 100 jobs as it continues to struggle with gloomy trading conditions and lower earnings.

item.title: Nothing to fear from virus vaccine: govt
item.description: The federal health minister has been quick to dispel myths about the safety of a vaccine that is to be extended to Australian schoolboys next year.

item.title: Sharks angry at illegal NRL tactic claims
item.description: Ben Ross has denied the Sydney Roosters' claims that Cronulla players are coached to run in an illegal and dangerous manner.

item.title: Iluka lifts revenue amid plunging sales
item.description: Iluka has lifted revenue by 16.2 per cent to $662.8 million in the first half despite sales dropping by more than a third.

item.title: Weak jobs data boosts chance of rate cut
item.description: Another interest rate cut could be on the way after the release of weaker-than-expected employment data.

item.title: Full-time employment drops by 33,500
item.description: The number of people in full-time employment tumbled by 33,500 in June, suggesting there could be more interest rate cuts to come.

item.title: Rio Tinto CFO to retire in 2013
item.description: Guy Elliott will end his 32-year career with Rio Tinto when he retires from the resources giant in 2013.

item.title: Aust dollar down on jobs data
item.description: The Australian dollar fell following the release of Australian employment figures

item.title: $A down on jobs data
item.description: The Australian dollar fell following the release of Australian employment figures

item.title: Govt defends need to keep internet data
item.description: Both Labor and the coalition agree on need to balance national security needs with an individual's right to privacy of phone and internet data.

item.title: Aussie jobless rate rose to 5.2% in June
item.description: Australia's jobless rate increased last month, new figures show.

item.title: Financial markets could inflate $A: RBA
item.description: Demand for the Australian dollar in financial markets could keep the currency higher than is justified by the state of the economy, the RBA warns.

item.title: Carr welcomes report Seoul to revoke whaling plan
item.description: Australia's Foreign Affairs Minister Bob Carr is seeking to clarify reports that South Korea is backing away from its plans to start scientific whaling.

item.title: PM cautious on defence abuse report
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard says the government is not in the business of putting defence sexual abuse allegations "out there".

item.title: Ioane, Gill back for Reds against Waratahs
item.description: Wallabies winger Digby Ioane and flanker Liam Gill have bolstered the Queensland Reds for their must-win Super Rugby match against the NSW Waratahs.

item.title: Telstra offloads NZ subsidiary for $A660m
item.description: Vodafone is buying Telstra's New Zealand communications subsidiary TelstraClear for $A660m.

item.title: Bonds higher on weak jobs data
item.description: The Australian bond market rose after the release of weak jobs data showing that the unemployment rate rose to 5.2 per cent in June.

item.title: Transurban annual revenues rise to $943.9m
item.description: Transurban says the revenues it collects from its toll roads rose by 5.9% to $943.9 million in the year to June 30.

item.title: NSW cops close to grabbing Kelly's killer
item.description: Police say the man who killed Sydney teen Thomas Kelly in a random attack in Kings Cross can expect a knock on the door from authorities soon.

item.title: ACCC had 600 carbon complaints in 10 days
item.description: The competition watchdog says it has received more than 600 complaints or inquiries on price claims with the carbon tax.

item.title: G20 needs Qld's biggest security plan
item.description: The head of Queensland's police union says the 2014 G20 meeting in Brisbane will be the state's biggest security operation.

item.title: Coles workers to consider wage offer
item.description: Workers at a key Coles warehouse will consider a new offer to workers in a bid to end the strike action, which will enter its third day on Thursday.

item.title: Crean tells MP to talk to real people
item.description: Regional Development Minister Simon Crean says talk about opinion polls, leadership and preference deals is limited to Canberra.

item.title: Swan to mark 40 yrs of China diplomacy
item.description: Treasurer Wayne Swan says Australia and China will continue to seek opportunities for both nations to boost their economies in the Asian Century.

item.title: Stocks to watch at close on Thursday
item.description: Stocks of interest on the Australian Securities Exchange at close on Thursday

item.title: International markets roundup
item.description: News from the world’s major stock markets

item.title: Commodities markets summary
item.description: Commodities news from around the world

item.title: Grafton protesters lose fight to keep jail
item.description: About 300 protesters have allowed prison vans to enter Grafton jail after ending a five-day blockade to prevent the 250-bed facility from being downgraded.

item.title: Hodge and Cummins in BBL defections
item.description: The Melbourne Stars have recruited Brad Hodge and Glenn Maxwell from the Renegades and Pat Cummins will play for Perth in the Big Bash League.

item.title: Aust share market closes lower
item.description: Disappointing jobs figures and negative reaction to commentary from the US central bank have helped drive down the Australian share market.

item.title: Dollar drops on weak labour force data
item.description: The Australian dollar dropped below 102 US cents after official data showed the unemployment rate rose to 5.2 per cent in June.

item.title: Power bills lead way in new tax complaints
item.description: THE Australian Competition and Consumer Commission said it has received only 630 complaints and enquiries about the carbon tax during its first 10 days, with most concerning electricity and gas bills.

item.title: Rural towns face final frontier as climate change looms
item.description: THE tourism blurb says White Cliffs, an opal mining town in the far west corner of NSW, has a ''last-frontier kind of appeal''. But a new report for the federal government says White Cliffs is the most vulnerable town in Australia to the impact of climate change. By 2050, Dubbo may be the western frontier as local economies in the hottest parts of the state succumb to the changing weather.

item.title: Brown lashes Labor's 'big end of town' view
item.description: Former Greens leader Bob Brown accuses Labor of dumping its constituency and launches a scathing attack on Resources Minister Martin Ferguson.

item.title: Churches object to Nile's party name change
item.description: Melbourne Anglican Archbishop asks the Victorian Electoral Commission not to let the Christian Democratic Party change its name to Australian Christians.

item.title: Coles gains reprieve in NSW
item.description: Coles is forced to the national industrial tribunal to prevent strike action from breaking out at its food warehouses across Australia's east.

item.title: Captain defied order on boat
item.description: Tony Abbott's pledge to turn boats back to Indonesia depends on the compliance of navy commanders - one of whom is celebrated in a navy publication for defying such orders.

item.title: Rider in Games sponsor clash
item.description: The notorious battlefield of Olympic-year advertising threatens to ensnare the golden girl of Australian track cycling, Anna Meares.

item.title: Spies want our net data
item.description: Agencies want access to texts and social media sites under a suite of new proposals from Australia's intelligence community.

item.title: Focus on family planning as Carr doubles foreign aid
item.description: AS WORLD leaders convene for a major family planning summit in London, the Foreign Affairs Minister, Bob Carr, said Australia would double its overseas aid for family planning programs to more than $50 million a year by 2016.

item.title: Australia has role in 'God particle' research
item.description: Australia's synchrotron is being used to pioneer new technology, as scientists seek to learn more about the newest particle discovered.

item.title: Duck producer in trouble over 'false claim' ads
item.description: Consumer authorities are suing Australia's largest duck producer after activists filmed its 'open range' ducks crowded into dirty pens.

item.title: New code puts a cap on telco sweet talk
item.description: CUSTOMER service in the telco sector may improve over the next two years, thanks to a new code governing advertising, account management and complaint handling in a sector notorious for high complaint levels.

item.title: New pay offer for Coles workers
item.description: Striking Coles workers in Melbourne will vote on a new wage offer today even though the union says it does not address the five key points of contention. Toll, which manages staff at the Somerton warehouse on behalf of Coles, yesterday presented union officials with an updated offer in a bid to end the strike, which will continue into its third day today. Two hundred workers continued to picket the gates of the key Coles warehouse in Melbourne's north after its 600 workers stopped work on 6am Tuesday, preventing goods from going in or out of the site. Workers will meet at 2pm to discuss a new offer. The National Union of Workers Victorian secretary, Tim Kennedy, said the offer did not meet the needs of workers in the five issues they want addressed, but members had a right to hear the offer and to vote on whether to accept it.

item.title: Sandilands rant not aggressive, says lawyer
item.description: AN ON-AIR tirade by 2DayFM radio presenter Kyle Sandilands in which he described a journalist as a ''fat slag'' and threatened to hunt her down was not aggressive or vitriolic in tone, but ''conversational'', a lawyer representing the station says.

item.title: All about the importance of 'acting with integrity'
item.description: TONY ABBOTT'S pledge to turn boats back to Indonesia depends on the compliance of navy commanders, one of whom is celebrated in an official navy publication for defying such orders during the Howard government.

item.title: Carr and Indonesia unite against Abbott asylum boats pledge
item.description: AUSTRALIA'S relationship with Indonesia is at ''full throttle'' and the Opposition Leader, Tony Abbott, was deluded to think he would strengthen it to the point the Indonesians would tolerate him turning back asylum seeker boats, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bob Carr, said.

item.title: Clean Up Australia's money troubles are just a bump in the road, says Kiernan
item.description: THE founder of Clean up Australia, Ian Kiernan, has vowed that Australia's largest annual community environmental event will go ahead next year despite the organisation retrenching its corporate staff and being hit with a sponsorship ''black hole''.

item.title: Climate change blamed for year of wild weather
item.description: WILD weather of unusual intensity dominated last year's global climate as greenhouse gas levels continued to climb and warm the atmosphere, according to the annual summary produced for the American Meteorological Society.

item.title: Dodson shows support for constitutional ban on racial discrimination
item.description: FORMER Australian of the year Mick Dodson has thrown his support behind a proposal to insert a ban on racial discrimination into the constitution, declaring such a move would ''cast out forever the dead legal and policy corpse of White Australia''.

item.title: Every click you make, they'll be watching
item.description: The telephone and internet data of every Australian will be retained for up to two years and intelligence agencies would be given increased access to social media sites, under a suite of new proposals from Australia's intelligence community.

item.title: Labor chiefs fear federal backlash in state polling
item.description: THE Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, has rejected claims that a potential Labor loss to the Greens in a Victorian by-election next week will be largely because of the unpopularity of the federal government.

item.title: Spy bid to keep our net data
item.description: The telephone and internet data of every Australian will be retained for up to two years and intelligence agencies would be given increased access to social media sites such as Facebook and Twitter, under a suite of new proposals from Australia's intelligence community.
